title: Cannot re-export everything using ES6
body:
Imports and exports are working correctly when using babelify, but if I re-export everything from another file:
```js
export * from './foo';
```

browserify fails when trying to find the dependencies before babelify can convert them:
```
Error: Parsing file /app/common/scripts/mycomponent/index.js: 'import' and 'export' may appear only with 'sourceType: module' (3:0)
    at Deps.parseDeps (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:454:28)
    at fromSource (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:391:44)
    at /app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:385:17
    at ConcatStream.<anonymous> (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/concat-stream/index.js:36:43)
    at emitNone (events.js:72:20)
    at ConcatStream.emit (events.js:166:7)
    at finishMaybe (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/concat-stream/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_writable.js:475:14)
    at endWritable (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/concat-stream/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_writable.js:485:3)
    at ConcatStream.Writable.end (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/concat-stream/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_writable.js:455:41)
    at DuplexWrapper.onend (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_readable.js:504:10)
    at DuplexWrapper.g (events.js:260:16)
    at emitNone (events.js:72:20)
    at DuplexWrapper.emit (events.js:166:7)
    at endReadableNT (/app/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_readable.js:926:12)
    at nextTickCallbackWith2Args (node.js:442:9)
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:356:17)
```

For reference this is the call in the gulpfile:
```js
  var b = browserify({
      entries: [`projects/${project}/scripts/app.js`],
      paths: ['common/scripts'],
      debug: true,
    });

    var plugins = [
      'transform-runtime',
      'transform-object-rest-spread',
      replaceVue,
    ];
    return b
      .transform('babelify', {
        presets: ['es2015'],
        extensions: ['.js', '.vue'],
        plugins: plugins,
      })
      .bundle()
      .on('error', function(err) {
        throw err;
      })
      .pipe(source('app.js'))
      .pipe(gulp.dest('tmp/assets/static/scripts'));
```

title: BAD: readable paths in bundled js cause browsers and crawlers to try prefetching the source
body:
Hey guys,

we had an issue with some strange requests to our site.
We could brake it down to the readable paths in the browserifyed script.

Some browsers and bots try to prefetch/crawl everything that looks like an url.
So all the paths where interpreted as urls and crawled.

After a very painful research we found https://github.com/substack/bundle-collapser.
It solves our issue.

I recommend you guys to include this feature as default into browserify.
Or at least make the repository easier to find...
The reasons are stated above.

Maybe we are doing sth really wrong here... feedback and corrections are very welcome!
Greetings
/ben

title: Fix usage of deprecated Buffer API
body:
```
(node:23274) DeprecationWarning: Using Buffer without `new` will soon stop working. Use `new Buffer()`, or preferably `Buffer.from()`, `Buffer.allocUnsafe()` or `Buffer.alloc()` instead.
```

See #1616. Only tests were affected.

Once Node.js 0.12 reaches EOL (January 1 2017), or whenever you feel comfortable with dropping 0.12 support, you can safely remove the "safe-buffer" dependency and the `require`s.

title: "Cannot find module" exception for "virtual" Vinyl 2.0.0 files
detecting dynamically generated requirements
Edge 35 issue and stream-http
body: I've recently fixed an issue related with stream-http. GET requests via http library doesn't work on Edge 35. Would you upgrade stream-http dependency in browserify to get this change?

title: Module gets loaded later then being used in file?
noParse not working
body: noParse does not work unless the file path is absolute. I've spent a long time nailing down why. browserify doesn't pass noParse to browser-deps as absolute paths. browser-deps requires absolute paths. It does compute absolute paths for its own use.

title: Warn if entries is missing.
body:
A gulp script is normally written in standard JavaScript with no warnings if option object is wrong. I just used a couple of hour debugging because of a stupid typo in the option object. I typed entris instead of entries.

So an improvement may be to warn if important options is missing (no files or entries)?

title: Question: Scope of browserified dependencies
body:
Hey everyone,

first of all, thanks for this great tool.
I use it for bundling a promise framework (bluebird) with my client script.
It works all well in Firefox, when adding my client script with bundled bluebird.
I'm able to send requests and process the results with .then and .catch handlers without having to reference bluebird from the file that includes my bundled client.
In IE (11) however, I can see that the promises are created properly in my client and even sent, but afterwards I receive an error, that Promise is undefined.
So it seems as if Promise only existed in my client scope and not in the files that use it.

So now I'm wondering, which of those behaviours is the intended one and how can I make sure, that bluebird is available in my client, but also in the files using it, for IE and Firefox?
If it is of any help, [this](https://github.com/DigitalFlow/Xrm-WebApi-Client/blob/master/src/js/WebApiClient.js) is my client.

Thanks for your help.

Kind Regards,
Florian

title: How to force standalone library (window.xxxxx) even in presence of AMD loaders?
body:
I'm developing a single JS file widget built with browserify. The idea is to place it in any website by means of a legacy `<script>` tag and let the website application use it via the global `window.mywidget`.

I've found a [website](http://configurator.mclaren.com/configuration/startConfiguration.do?profileName=COUPE570S) using [Dojo Toolkit](https://dojotoolkit.org/) in which my widget does not run at all. I've realized that it happens due to this check in the bundled fie:

``` js
if (typeof define==="function" && define.amd) { define([],f) }
```

I understand that the website application could use its own AMD loader to load and use my widget, but certainly it may not be the case and I still need `window.mywidget` to exist.

How to deal with this scenario?

title: `b.require` doesn't generate 'requrire' function... in certain really odd cases
body:
Ok, I'm mainly raising this in the hopes someone who knows the code really well has an "aha" moment.

Here's a minimal test case:

browserifyTest.js:

```
"use strict";
let browserify = require('browserify');
let b = browserify();
b.require('./foo');
b.bundle().pipe(process.stdout);
```

foo.js:

```
exports.foo = function() {console.log("Hello world");};
```

Super simple.  If you try this with browserify v13.1.0, it will work, and it will generate a file that starts with:

```
require=function e(t,n,r){...
```

This is generating our global `require` function for other js files to use.

So, here's my problem.  I have a project where, if I delete node_modules and do a fresh install (with browserify v13.1.0 in my package.json), and I try the above example, I get a file that starts with:

```
!function e(t,n,r){...
```

Which, obviously, does _not_ generate the global require function.  Ok, that's weird, so then I:

```
npm install browserify@11.0.1
```

Because this is the version we were using about a month ago, and now my little test above works.  And then I:

```
npm install browserify@13.1.0
```

And now my test _still_ works.  Wat?

My guess is there's something odd going on with npm and the order it is installing packages (guess it's time to try this "yarn" thing everyone is talking about).  After the downgrade and upgrade, /node_modules now contains "umd" and "immutable".  "browserify" and  "browserify-middleware" suspiciously have a bunch of extra stuff in their node_modules folder (including "browser-pack").

What is going on here?  O_o

title: Improve documentation for javascript API
body:
Hi, all, I'm new to `browserify`, so, please forgive me if this issue sound noobish ... it might righteously be.

I have to integrate `browserify` into a Gulp task and, so, I referred to the [documentation about its methods](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify#methods), but it is **not** very user friendly and I think that it might be incomplete.

Do you, guys, have any plan on improving this documentation or, otherwise, could provide a better source?

title: If window.self is overridden by the website, browserified files added later fail
body:
This site, http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/, defines a `self` variable in `window` namespace (in fact, it overrides the existing one):

```
> self
Object {requires: Array[2], data: Object, internal: Object, id: "IKEA.Utility.Browser.FeatureSupport"}bindClick: (c)create: (d,c)data: ObjectgetDevicePixelRatio: ()getInternetExplorerVersion: ()getScrollHeight: ()id: "IKEA.Utility.Browser.FeatureSupport"init: ()internal: ObjectisGeolocationAvailable: (a)isMobile: ()isMobileSafari: ()isSafari: ()keepFieldinViewOnAndroid: ()onPageLoad: (b)pageLoad: ()repaintTridentBrowser: ()requires: Array[2]__proto__: Object
```

If any browserified file is later loaded into that website, the `global` managed by browserify does not becomes `window` but the existing global `self` variable.

This is the head of browserified files:

``` js
(function(f){if(typeof exports==="object"&&typeof module!=="undefined"){module.exports=f()}else if(typeof define==="function"&&define.amd){define([],f)}else{var g;if(typeof window!=="undefined"){g=window}else if(typeof global!=="undefined"){g=global}else if(typeof self!=="undefined"){g=self}else{g=this}
```

Here the issue:

``` js
if (typeof self !== "undefined") { g=self }
```

Is there any way to prevent this problem?

title: Can't get file name in the error event
Using less in browserify
Clarification of Treatment of __dirname When Using --node Switch in Documentation
body: The documentation currently refers to "inserting" the __dirname symbol when the --node switch is used. Upon inspecting the bundle, it actually replaces each occurrence of __dirname with the full path to that js file. This should be mentioned in the docs that this happens at compile time. If a user wishes to use the full path to the bundle at runtime then node's process.cwd() should be used. If there is sufficient interest in clarifying this then I will open a PR with the requisite changes.

I was wondering if there's any way I could run browserify only to import the required modules into the script but leave the `module.exports` declaration intact and also do not wrap it so the browser can still look for it? I hope this makes sense.

Thanks in advance

title: Please update your package.json to use the latest punycode module 2.0.0 ASAP
[discussion] Reducing the size of your browserify builds
body: So you have browserified your code, and the resulting bundle is much bigger that you would like. What steps do you go through to make it smaller?

title: Referencing an exposed module by its path fails with fullPaths option
body:
Minimal reproduction: https://github.com/niallwingham/browserify-full-paths-bug

There is a bug caused by the `fullPaths` option, when one of the bundled modules requires an exposed module using a path.  The exposed module is available under its alias, but not under its file path.  The bug is avoided when `fullPaths` is not used because both the file path and the alias are mapped to an index by deps-sort.

I'm happy to contribute a pull request to resolve this.  It could be fixed by doing a similar mapping in deps-sort when the `index` option is false, if we want to address it there.  But I'm not sure if it should be the job of deps-sort to correct dependency mappings; maybe this belongs in module-deps or elsewhere.  Please advise!

title: Update package.json
body: Use latest version of glob to avoid node security issues.

title: Use svg travis badge
Browserify doesn't use $NODE_PATH to resolve transforms
body:
This:

``` bash
NODE_PATH=/some/path
browserify -t foo main.js > bundle.js
```

...fails when `foo` is resolved at `/some/path`. Also created a related PR here: https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/120 regarding cases where dependencies' transforms were failing to load for similar reasons.

title: External modules still being bundled
body:
[package.zip](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/files/470294/package.zip)
In a specific situation (when I try to browserify my jasmine tests), some of the modules marked as external (like react) are included to the bundle as well.

```
var bundler = browserify({
  basedir: '.',
  debug: true,
  entries: ["spec/fooSpec.ts"]
}).plugin(tsify)
  .external(['react', 'react-dom', 'react-router', 'react-bootstrap']);

gulp.task("compile-test", function () { 
    return bundler.bundle() //this bundles react although it is marked as external
      .pipe(source('tests2.js'))
      .pipe(gulp.dest("dist"))
});
```

however, when I try to browserify from another entry point, like `src/index.ts`, react is not bundled.

I've attached [working demo](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/files/470296/package.zip) that demostrates the problem.

just run 

```
npm install
gulp compile-tests
```

and check that react is included in the output file (tests2.js). However, when you run gulp-compile, which browserifies from another entry point, react is externalized

[working demo - package.zip](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/files/470296/package.zip)

title: Browserify + watchify + babelify. Increase a time of calling and number of times
Settings (transforms, plugins etc) disappear in sub-directories with package.json
body:
First off, the behaviour itself is probably correct, but it bit us anyway.

The situation: One largish project, containing several subfolders, using babelify to do es6 transpiling. Suddenly started to choke on later minification, turns out some es6 files weren't being transpiled. Took a while to find which files and then why: there was a package.json in that folder, which only was used to rename the main script from index.js (so they aren't all named that).

Since the package.json did not list transforms, the parent ones weren't applied.

This seems correct, but the problem was that it was silent, surprising and not that straightforward to get to the bottom of.

Possible solutions:
- Warnings - make noise in the log when this happens, easy to see, easy to fix
- Inherit settings - unless new transforms etc are specified, use them in subfolder too - probably usually what is expected
- Fail unless new settings (even empty) are explicitly specified

I'd be fine with a clear warning, but inheritance is probably what many would expect when there's no new browserify field at all.

title: update tests to use Buffer.from
body:
Using Buffer without new will soon stop working. It will throw
A deprecation warning in Node v7. This commit modifies the tests
in `test/bare.js` and `test/bare_shebang.js` to use the
`Buffer.from` interface instead. It is a drop in replacement for
Buffer that is supported by Node v4 / v6 and Browserify's Buffer
implementation

For the browserify test suite to pass on Node v7 we will need
to land this commit as well as the two below PR's
- https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/pull/75
- https://github.com/maxogden/concat-stream/pull/48

title: require doesn't work on files excluded from that bundle

This behavior works fine if used with Node modules though, like Lodash.

title: `Buffer()` without a `new` keyword is going to be hard-deprecated soon
body:
Refs: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/8169, https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/7152.

Two options here:
- Use the new Buffer API — `Buffer.alloc()`/`Buffer.from()`/`Buffer.allocUnsafe()` (requires [a shim](https://github.com/feross/safe-buffer) for v0.10/v0.12 and older v4.x versions prior to v4.5.0).
- Use `new Buffer()` for the time being — just add the `new` keyword everywhere. You should manually check that everything is safe in this case, see the links below for more explanation. That _might_ be hard-deprecated at some later point.

More background:
- https://github.com/ChALkeR/notes/blob/master/Lets-fix-Buffer-API.md
- https://github.com/ChALkeR/notes/blob/master/Buffer-knows-everything.md
- https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/7152#issuecomment-240880317

Quick grep (you should better re-check):

```
browserify-13.1.0.tgz/test/bare.js:34:    ps.stdin.end('console.log(Buffer("ABC"))');
browserify-13.1.0.tgz/test/bare_shebang.js:32:    ps.stdin.end('#!/usr/bin/env node\nconsole.log(Buffer("WOO"))');
browserify-13.1.0.tgz/test/global/buffer.js:1:t.equal(Buffer('xyz').toString('base64'), 'eHl6');
browserify-13.1.0.tgz/test/global/buffer.js:2:t.equal(Buffer('eHl6', 'base64').toString(), 'xyz');
browserify-13.1.0.tgz/test/leak.js:46:    stream.push('t.equal(Buffer("eHl6", "base64").toString(), "xyz")');
```

The grep above only includes the lines that call `Buffer()` without the `new` keyword, if you choose to move to the new API — you should probably also replace `new Buffer(…)` calls.

title: --ignore does not work without file extension
EMFILE: fs --> Graceful-fs
body:
Please consider replacing node fs package with graceful-fs. It helps a lot avoiding EMFILE errors especially on Windows (because there is no way to change the ULIMIT).

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8965606/node-and-error-emfile-too-many-open-files
https://www.npmjs.com/package/graceful-fs #1003 #431

title: Forward/Backward slash mismatch for external requires on Windows
body:
To reproduce, create two files - `/scripts/lib.js` & `/scripts/index.js`, with `index.js` requiring `libs.js`

Then run the following from the root directory:

```
browserify -r ./scripts/lib.js > ./scripts/lib-bundle.js
browserify -x ./scripts/lib.js ./scripts/index.js > ./scripts/index-bundle.js
```

Then load in a browser:

```
<script src="/scripts/lib-bundle.js"></script>
<script src="/scripts/index-bundle.js"></script>
```

...and we get the following error: `Uncaught Error: Cannot find module '/scripts\lib.js'`.

Inspecting the output files, we see the following files are exporting/requiring the following paths:

| platform | version | lib-bundle.js exports | index-bundle.js requires | works |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Windows | >=12.0.2 | `/scripts/lib.js` | `/scripts\\lib.js` | no |
| Windows | <=12.0.1 | `/scripts\\lib.js` | `/scripts\\lib.js` | yes |
| Linux | any | `/scripts/lib.js` | `/scripts/lib.js` | yes |

title: Windows Source Mapping Paths Wrong
body: In Windows, Source mapping contain a backslash and not a forward slash.  This causes Chrome to think the whole path is the file name.

title: Using require ignores nested dependencies with the same name as top-level required modules.
body:
I'm currently trying to create a common libraries bundle called "libs.js" file with both `plotly.js` and `d3` (and `jquery` but this is probably irrelevant). I'm using the command:

```
browserify -r jquery -r d3 -r plotly.js -o ./build/libs.js -d
```

This produces a "libs.js" but it only includes `./node_modules/d3` and not `./node_modules/plotly.js/node_modules/d3` which are of different `d3` versions (4.1.0 vs 3.5.17). `plotly.js` uses the older d3 version and cannot use the newer d3.

How do I make this bundle include both versions of d3 correctly?

title: Manually add bundle id to require function
body:
I asked this question here https://github.com/substack/factor-bundle/issues/88 but I think it can be solved with `browserify` without doing anything to `factor-bundle`. To solve this with `browserify` we need a way to manually add bundle id to require function so that when we call `require('a.j' + 's')` it can determine the id associated with `a.js`.

Suppose that I have:

```
// a.js:
require('./b.js').test()
require('./b.j' + 's').test()
```

```
// b.js
function test() {
    console.log(123);
}
```

Now suppose that I want to lazy load `b.js`. If I `browserify` `a.js` with `factor-bundle`, `b.js`'s content will end up in `common.js`. One workaround is changing `a.js` to something like this:

```
// a.js:
require('./b.j' + 's'').test()
require('./b.j' + 's'').test()
```

Now `b.js` will not be included in `common.js` and will be in its own bundle. The problem is the `require` function in `a.js`doesn't know about './b.js' now so it fails to require it.

Questions:
1. Is it possible to make the `require` in `a.js` aware of the id associated with './b.js'?
2. Generally is it the good approach? What are the best practices for achieving this?

P.S. `https://github.com/epeli/browserify-externalize` seems to try to solve this issue, but it's not maintained anymore.

body:

`browserify script.js -o bundle.js`

is resulting:

```
Error: Cannot find module './src/adb' from '/home/[user]/app/node_modules/adbkit'
at /usr/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:55:21
at load (/usr/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:69:43)
at onex (/usr/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:92:31)
at /usr/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:22:47
at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:107:15)
```

I have 'adbkit' installed globally and locally in my Express app, as demonstrated by my dependencies:

```
"dependencies": {
    "adbkit": "^2.4.1",
    ...
}
```

Similarly to [this](https://github.com/openstf/adbkit-apkreader/issues/2), for adbkit, adbkit-monkey, and adbkit-logcat I attempted to force each of their respective index.js files to reference `./lib/adb`, `./lib/monkey`, and `./lib/logcat` as it is for the JS environment.  Hardcoding to the correct directories then allows the bundle to be created, but then when I run the bundle with `node bundle.js` the following error occurs: `TypeError: Cannot read property 'prototype' of undefined`

What can I do for this to work?

title: Bad error message for invalid "browserify" entry in package.json
Invalid Mapping Source Map Generator Issue
Testing modules managed by Browersify
body:
I started using Browersify recently and I am struggling to write unit tests using Jasmine for modules in my application. 

For example I have a main module main.js that depends on module a.js and module a.js depends on another module b.js. 

Now I would like to unit test module A which looks like this

``` javascript
var b = require("./b");
module.exports = function (n) { return b.calculate(n) }
```

Also if I include in my jasmine tests both a.js and b.js scripts 
`module.exports = function (....)` from both file will override each other as `module` variable will be treated as global variable assuming it's initialized before somewhere in my test.

How can I mock out dependency on module b? I don't want to use real implementation of b as it might have also other dependencies my unit test shouldn't be concerned about.

My first idea was to write my own `require(module)` function that would return mocks that I could configure for specific tests. Is this the right approach?

title: Irrelevant error message confuses user
body:
See this Stack Overflow post:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38296350/browserify-syntaxerror-the-keyword-let-is-reserved/38336534#38336534

TL;DR:
Error message complained about `let` keywords, but the problem was a trailing comma in arguments to a function.

title: option to use a virtual file system instead of file ids
body:
I'm currently facing a situation where it would be useful if one bundle could require any file of another bundle. Specifically, I have a main application, that gets bundled, and I have some plugins that get bundled independently.

When a plugin gets loaded, it needs to be able to require some of the files of the main application and then call some functions on them to plug themselves in. But at bundling time of a plugin, the file ids of the files of the main bundle are unknown to the plugin. All it knows is the path to the file.

That leads me to the suggestion to introduce an option to use a virtual file system to store files inside of a bundle. So, instead of identifying the files by sequencial ids, they would be identified by their path relative to the specified basedir.

If i then load multiple bundles, they share one single virtual file system. This way, require could work the same way as it does on the server. Dynamic requires would still work, and of course, one bundle could require files of another bundle. This would open up many possibilities.

I know that there are also drawbacks to this:
- File size might get bigger, because paths take more space than numbers
- Possible security risk, because a hacker knows the structure of the file system

But since the file system would only get revealed up to the basedir, an attacker would at most get information about the applications internal file structure and not the one of the whole server.

What do you think? How do you estimate the amount of work needed for such a feature? Would this maybe even be possible through a plugin?

title: how to exclude my appcode from jasmine specs
Replace \\ with / in relative external paths
body:
Currently files required from other bundles imported like follows in Windows:

```
  bundler.external(['./assets/Master.js']);
```

will produce require calls as follows in the compiled file:

```
  var Master = require('/assets\\Master.js');
```

which will naturally fail. This fix replaces the double slashes with a single slash, like it's done in `Browserify.prototype.require`

title: reproduction demonstrating #1505
body:
See the new failing tests.

If you uncomment the code you can see why it is failing:

title: take shims out of core
body:
We currently have a difficult breaking change to integrate in crypto-browserify
https://github.com/crypto-browserify/pbkdf2/issues/34#issuecomment-228190327

But a problem is that we don't actually know what modules actually use it, because browserify injects it directly. when node introduces breaking changes, what version does browserify track?
Indeed, since modules do not specify the versions of the core modules they could break unexpectedly with new versions of node. the idea of removing them from core has been kicking around a while, https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/7098

Removing them from browserify would be much easier, because the browserify shims are already all maintained as separate repos, we'd just have to remove them as deps of browserify... use browserify's already existing config `"browser": {"<core_module>": "<core_module>-browserify"}`

and print a sufficiently helpful error message when a core module is required but not configured.
or possibly it would be okay to automatically resolve `<core_module>-browserify` for the official core modules?

title: Unifying CLI and API (constructor) options.
body:
Would you accept a patch that moved the CLI to [Commander.js](https://github.com/tj/commander.js/) (or [minimist](https://www.npmjs.com/package/minimist), [yargs](https://github.com/yargs/yargs), [dashdash](https://github.com/trentm/node-dashdash)), and that unified the logic behind processing local arguments with the CLI arguments? This will clear off stupid bugs like `node:true` in the API, and close out 

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1472
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1277
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1540
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1479
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1557
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1452

(there are a few more that we may argue it would have also clarified)

We have complex logic for the CLI arguments, and the API-constructor arguments and redundant documentation. This would simplify it. It would also make downstream bugs easier to solve rather than requiring a convoluted browserify configure that specifies all of the options for node.

https://github.com/kevinbeaty/any-promise/issues/23

title: Browserify child process exits before emitting entire bundle.
body:
In node if I execute the following:

``` js
require("child_process").exec("browserify app.js").stdout.pipe(process.stdout)
```

The stream closes before emitting the entire bundle.

If I put the above in a script named `test.js` and execute the following:

```
node test.js | uglifyjs -mc
```

Uglify complains that there are EOL syntax errors.

However, if I run `browserify app.js` or `browserify app.js | uglifyjs -mc` in the terminal it completes just fine and outputs a valid bundle.

This is the source that I am running it against: https://github.com/JAForbes/css-game-experiment.

title: Better Error Handling
body:
I find that myself and quite a few other people online seem to run into some variation of an error like this sonner or later:

```
...
events.js:72
        throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
              ^
...
```

For example, simply running `browserify file.js -o out.js` will output this cryptic (unhandled) error while doing `browserify file.js` actually outputs the contents of the `er` which proves to be far more useful.

This has happened during syntax errors, tree shaking, and a lot of other things. It's happened across devices, platforms, and just always lends to a lot of tedious debugging and testing just to figure out what exactly IS `er`.

Is there ANY way that browserify can implement better error logging or reporting? Like simply adding a flag that ALWAYS outputs the contents of the error instead of throwing a fairly vague error event?

I feel this would make things IMMENSELY easier for a lot of browserify consumers.

title: Bad paths in source maps with --node switch and use of __filename or __dirname
body:
Browserify version 13.0.1.

I'm seeing an issue on both Windows and Mac where the "sources" entries in the source map are incorrectly generated when using the --node switch, but _only_ when the __dirname or __filename global variables are referenced in code.

That is, any file that references either __dirname or __filename will receive a strangely mangled  "sources" path, but any file that doesn't receives a normal "sources" path.

For example, instead of this:

```
  "sources": [
    "src/good.js",
    "src/node_modules/goodness.js"
  ]
```

I get this:

```
  "sources": [
    "src\\Users\\someuser\\Desktop\\BadSourceMap\\src\\bad.js",
    "src\\node_modules\\Users\\someuser\\Desktop\\BadSourceMap\\src\\node_modules\\badness.js"
  ]
```

where `bad.js` and `badness.js` both reference one of the variables, but `good.js` and `goodness.js` do not.

There seems to somehow be a direct relationship between referencing the variables from within a file and having a mangled "sources" entry emitted for that file.  If the variable references are removed from the file, then the "sources" path is okay again.

Very weird, but I imagine there is some sort of unexpected side-effect or data corruption going on inside browserify, while processing __dirname or __filename references in code, that somehow affects the subsequent generation of source map paths.

(Btw, on Windows, the actual path strings inserted into the generated code for __dirname and __filename variables references can contain an odd mix of forward and back slashes.  It would be nice if they were normalized.)

To repro, download and expand [BadSourceMap.zip](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/files/273492/BadSourceMap.zip) into a folder on your system.

Then, at the command prompt, cd to the folder and run:

```
> npm install
> npm run good
> npm run bad
```

Examine and compare the following files output to the folder:

```
generated-good.js
generated-good.js.map
generated-bad.js
generated-bad.js.map
```

title: relative excludes
body:
```
- src
  - ./header.js
  - main.js <- browserify target this file - has requires ('./header.js') and require ('foo-bar')
```

now for browserify I explicity ask browserify to exclude `./header.js`

``` javascript

# ./main.js

var headers = require ('./headers.js') # browserify correctly ignores, YAY ! :) 
var foo_bar = require ('foo-bar')

```

so lets look at foo-bar

```
foo-bar directory

- node_modules
   - foo-bar
     - dist
       - header.js
       - main.js <- entry file has require ('./header.js')
```

browserify unfortunately also ignores ./header.js in foo bar :(

@substack - what do ?

cheers !

title: browserify --node with require.extentions
body:
This seems to not work.  Sorry if I missed another issue that mentions it, but I am using version `12.0.2` and doing a command like this:

```
$ browserify --node -t [babelify] --debug -u tinyliquid [A bunch of other ignores...] bin/app -o build/bin/app
```

One of the modules that it includes is [`consolidate`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/consolidate), which uses `require.extentions` to modify imports.  I am probably going to move away from that package after having these issues and seeing that it registers those hooks whether or not we are using that template engine, but the issue stands that I cannot run my bundle in node if it runs anything that uses that feature.

I looked at https://github.com/substack/browser-pack and see that maybe the issue is in the prelude, that it would need to include proxying the `require.extentions` field, but figured this issue is better opened here for discussion.  Tell me if you would rather this be moved somewhere else (edit: or closed) :)

_Also I understand that bundling the app together means that `require.extentions` is not used, regardless the code doesn't run._

title: sourcemap contains some absolute paths instead of relative path
body:
Hi,

I run the following command:
`browserify --debug /paths/of/my/sources | exorcist aggregate.js.map | uglifyjs -cm > aggregate.js`

My `package.json` file:

```
  {
    "dependencies": {
        "flux": "^2.0.1",
        "keymirror": "~0.1.0",
        "object-assign": "^1.0.0",
        "react": "^0.13.3",
        "lodash": "^3.10.0"
    },
    "devDependencies": {
        "envify": "^3.0.0",
        "reactify": "^1.1.1",
        "uglify-js": "~2.4.15",
        "watchify": "^3.2.3",
        "browserify": "^13.0.1",
        "exorcist": "^0.4.0"
    },
    "browserify": {
        "transform": [
            "reactify",
            "envify"
        ]
    }
  }
```

What is really strange is that some sources in my sourcemap file are relative to my working directory (expected behavior) while others are referenced as absolute paths:

```
    "node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-pack/_prelude.js",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/Header.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/app/actions/AppConst.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/app/components/App.react.js",
    "app/js/app/stores/AppStore",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/colAndRow/actions/ColAndRowActions.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/colAndRow/actions/ColAndRowConst.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/colAndRow/components/Column.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/colAndRow/components/UserRow.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/colAndRow/stores/ColAndRowStore.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/common/components/EditableText.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/dispatcher/AppDispatcher.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/kanban/actions/KanbanActions.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/kanban/actions/KanbanConst.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/kanban/components/Kanban.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/kanban/components/mixins/KanbanStickyManager.jsx",
    "app/js/kanban/model/KanbanModelBuilder",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/kanban/stores/KanbanStore.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/main.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/overview/actions/PreviewActions.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/overview/actions/PreviewConst.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/overview/components/Overview.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/overview/components/Preview.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/sticky/actions/StickyActions.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/sticky/actions/StickyConst.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/sticky/components/AddStickyButton.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/sticky/components/CollapseStickiesButton.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/sticky/components/Ghost.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/sticky/components/Sticky.react.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/sticky/components/mixins/StickyMixin.jsx",
    "app/js/sticky/stores/StickyStore",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/util/EventHelper.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/util/Labels.jsx",
    "/absolute/path/to/source/app/js/util/ZoomZoneLabelManager.jsx"
```

What I see is that the absolite path is used when the file ends with `.jsx` or `.react.js` while the relative path is normally added when the file ends with `.js`

Any idea?

Regards

title: Getting an "Object is not a constructor error" why trying to browserify an npm module I wrote
Inconsistency between browserified version and native node version
body:
I've got a relatively simple test case here that shows a simple function that produces different output when run through browserify and when run in node directly:

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/927666/test.zip

I've included the shrinkwrap, actual node_modules folder, and output of running browserify. To test you can simply compare the result of running `node index.js` with `node compiled.js`.

I previously believed this was due to a bug in crypto-browserify directly, which you can see here:

https://tonicdev.com/boucher/57193b9ee517ca11004e25ed

But I'm not so sure now, because re-running a similar test by requiring crypto-browserify directly in node produces a correct result, while the browserified version is still incorrect.
